review.title: A Survey on Domain-Specific Languages for Machine Learning in Big Data
review.abstract: The amount of data generated in the modern society is increasing rapidly. New problems and novel approaches of data capture, storage, analysis and visualization are responsible for the emergence of the Big Data research field. Machine Learning algorithms can be used in Big Data to make better and more accurate inferences. However, because of the challenges Big Data imposes, these algorithms need to be adapted and optimized to specific applications. One important decision made by software engineers is the choice of the language that is used in the implementation of these algorithms. Therefore, this literature survey identifies and describes domain-specific languages and frameworks used for Machine Learning in Big Data. By doing this, software engineers can then make more informed choices and beginners have an overview of the main languages used in this domain.

metadata.title: A Survey on Domain-Specific Languages for Machine Learning in Big Data

referenceMentions.context: The evolution of technology in the last decades caused a major data revolution [72].

However, applications of Machine Learning in Big Data have to overcome several Big Data challenges [38].

OptiML [12][25][62] is a DSL designed as a research project from Stanford University’s Pervasive Parallelism Laboratory with the goal of enabling Machine Learning algorithms to take advantage of parallelism.

OptiML [12][25][62] is a DSL designed as a research project from Stanford University’s Pervasive Parallelism Laboratory with the goal of enabling Machine Learning algorithms to take advantage of parallelism.

OptiML [12][25][62] is a DSL designed as a research project from Stanford University’s Pervasive Parallelism Laboratory with the goal of enabling Machine Learning algorithms to take advantage of parallelism.
OptiML runs on top of Delite [63], a compiler framework developed by the same research team, and supports operations with the basic three types: vector, matrix, and graph.
Its operations supports parallel executions (using the MapReduce programming model [18]) in heterogeneous machines, which are machines that have more than one type of processor or core.

ScalOps [8][71] is a DSL with the goal of enabling Machine Learning algorithms to run on a cloud computing environment and overcoming a limitation of the traditional MapReduce programming model: the lack of iteration.

ScalOps [8][71] is a DSL with the goal of enabling Machine Learning algorithms to run on a cloud computing environment and overcoming a limitation of the traditional MapReduce programming model: the lack of iteration.
To support iterations in MapReduce, ScalOps designers introduced an enhanced version of the programming model called Map-Reduce-Update [8].

SCOPE [13] is a DSL developed by Microsoft to account for the distributed and cloud computing challenges in querying and managing data.
Data is stored in Cosmos Storage System [13], also developed by Microsoft.
Sawzall [52] is a DSL developed by engineers at Google.

metadata.abstractText: The amount of data generated in the modern society is increasing rapidly. New problems and novel approaches of data capture, storage, analysis and visualization are responsible for the emergence of the Big Data research field. Machine Learning algorithms can be used in Big Data to make better and more accurate inferences. However, because of the challenges Big Data imposes, these algorithms need to be adapted and optimized to specific applications. One important decision made by software engineers is the choice of the language that is used in the implementation of these algorithms. Therefore, this literature survey identifies and describes domain-specific languages and frameworks used for Machine Learning in Big Data. By doing this, software engineers can then make more informed choices and beginners have an overview of the main languages used in this domain. Keywords—literature survey; domain-specific languages; DSL; Machine Learning; ML; Big Data; BD
